title: Relates to the power authority of the state of New York and the public authorities control board
summary: Relates to the power authority of the state of New York and the public authorities control board; prohibits the power authority from undertaking any project or sale of any asset exceeding one million dollars without the approval from the public authorities control board; provides for factors for such determination; creates a temporary special commission on the restructuring of the power authority of the state of New York; directs the New York state energy research and development authority to conduct studies related to the state's electric transmission system, the state's natural gas infrastructure and a comprehensive energy plan for the down state region of the state.

       Introduced  by  Sens.  PARKER,  DIAZ,  DUANE, HASSELL-THOMPSON, KRUEGER,
         KRUGER, PERKINS, SAMPSON, SERRANO, STAVISKY -- read twice and  ordered

         and Telecommunications

       AN ACT to amend the public authorities law, in  relation  to  the  power
         authority  of the state of New York and the public authorities control
         board, and in relation to directing the New York state energy research
         and development authority to conduct studies related  to  the  state's
         electric  transmission  system, the state's natural gas infrastructure
         and a comprehensive energy plan for the downstate region of the state

         THE PEOPLE OF THE STATE OF NEW YORK, REPRESENTED IN SENATE AND  ASSEM-
       BLY, DO ENACT AS FOLLOWS:

    1    Section  1.  Subdivision 1 of section 51 of the public authorities law
    2  is amended by adding a new paragraph o to read as follows:
    3    O. POWER AUTHORITY OF THE STATE OF NEW YORK
    4    S 2. Section 1005 of the public authorities law is amended by adding a
    5  new subdivision 11-a to read as follows:
    6    11-A. NOTWITHSTANDING ANY OTHER PROVISION OF LAW TO THE CONTRARY,  THE
    7  AUTHORITY SHALL NOT UNDERTAKE ANY PROJECT OR SALE OF ANY ASSET EXCEEDING
    8  ONE MILLION DOLLARS IN VALUE WITHOUT THE APPROVAL OF THE PUBLIC AUTHORI-
    9  TIES  CONTROL  BOARD  CREATED PURSUANT TO ARTICLE ONE-A OF THIS CHAPTER.
   10  EACH APPLICATION TO THE PUBLIC AUTHORITIES CONTROL BOARD SHALL CONTAIN A
   11  PROJECT DESCRIPTION OR DESCRIPTION OF SALE AND AN EXPLANATION OF WHY THE
   12  PROJECT OR SALE MEETS THE STANDARDS FOR PROJECT APPROVAL OR APPROVAL  OF
   13  SALE SET FORTH IN THIS SUBDIVISION. THE PUBLIC AUTHORITIES CONTROL BOARD
   14  SHALL  ONLY APPROVE A PROJECT OR SALE PROPOSED BY THE AUTHORITY UPON ITS
   15  DETERMINATION THAT:
   16    A. THE PROJECT OR SALE IS FINANCIALLY  FEASIBLE  AS  THE  STANDARD  AS
   17  DEFINED IN ARTICLE ONE-A OF THIS CHAPTER;

        EXPLANATION--Matter in ITALICS (underscored) is new; matter in brackets
                             [ ] is old law to be omitted.
                                                                  LBD02114-01-1

       S. 1056                             2

    1    B.  THE  PROJECT  OR  SALE IS ANTICIPATED TO RESULT GENERALLY IN LOWER
    2  UTILITY RATES IN THE STATE; AND
    3    C.  THE  PROJECT  OR SALE WILL NOT MATERIALLY ADVERSELY AFFECT OVERALL
    4  REAL PROPERTY TAXES OR UTILITY RATES IN ANY AREAS OF THE  STATE  OF  NEW
    5  YORK.
    6    S 3. Temporary special commission on restructuring the power authority
    7  of  the state of New York. 1. There shall be a temporary special commis-
    8  sion on restructuring the power authority of  the  state  of  New  York,
    9  which  shall possess the powers and duties as specified in this section,
   10  and also all powers necessary or proper to  enable  such  commission  to
   11  carry  out  the  purposes  for  which  it  is established. The temporary
   12  special commission shall consist of eight members as follows:    two  of
   13  whom  shall be appointed by the governor, two of whom shall be appointed
   14  by the temporary president of the senate, two of whom shall be appointed
   15  by the speaker of the assembly, one of whom shall be  appointed  by  the
   16  minority  leader of the senate and one of whom shall be appointed by the
   17  minority leader of the assembly. Each member shall serve at the pleasure
   18  of the respective appointing person.  One of the  members  appointed  by
   19  the  governor shall be selected by the governor to serve as chair of the
   20  temporary special commission. The temporary special commission shall  be
   21  subject  to articles 6 and 7 of the public officers law.  Each member of
   22  the temporary special commission shall be subject to the  provisions  of
   23  article 4 of the public officers law.
   24    2. The temporary special commission on restructuring the power author-
   25  ity of the state of New York shall have the power and duty to:
   26    (a)  conduct  hearings, discussions, and negotiations among members of
   27  the public, affected businesses, and representatives of government; and
   28    (b) issue a final report to the  governor  and  legislature  detailing
   29  recommendations on restructuring the power authority of the state of New
   30  York,  including, but not limited to, the following issues: the divesti-
   31  ture of  such  authority's  non-hydroelectric  generation  assets;  such
   32  authority's  role  as  a transmission provider; such authority's role in
   33  the power for jobs and economic development power programs; such author-
   34  ity's energy efficiency programs; such  authority's  relationship  with,
   35  and  obligation  to,  host  communities,  including, but not limited to,
   36  payments-in-lieu of taxes to local municipalities and school  districts,
   37  economic  development  investments,  and community revitalization initi-
   38  atives; and such authority's role in a deregulated energy market. On  or
   39  before  September  1, 2012 such commission shall transmit such report to
   40  the governor, the speaker of the assembly, the minority  leader  of  the
   41  assembly,  the temporary president of the senate, the minority leader of
   42  the senate, the chairman of the assembly energy committee and the chair-
   43  man of the senate energy and telecommunications committee.
   44    S 4. The public  authorities  law  is  amended  by  adding  three  new
   45  sections 1855-a, 1855-b and 1855-c to read as follows:
   46    S  1855-A.  ELECTRIC  TRANSMISSION  CONGESTION STUDY. 1. THE AUTHORITY
   47  SHALL UNDERTAKE A STUDY OF THE OVERALL ADEQUACY OF THE STATE'S  ELECTRIC
   48  TRANSMISSION  SYSTEM. THE AUTHORITY MAY CONTRACT WITH AN INDEPENDENT AND
   49  COMPETITIVELY SELECTED CONTRACTOR TO UNDERTAKE SUCH STUDY. THE AUTHORITY
   50  SHALL PREPARE A REPORT ON ITS FINDINGS AND LEGISLATIVE  RECOMMENDATIONS.
   51  ON  OR  BEFORE SEPTEMBER FIRST, TWO THOUSAND TWELVE, THE AUTHORITY SHALL
   52  TRANSMIT SUCH REPORT TO THE GOVERNOR, THE  TEMPORARY  PRESIDENT  OF  THE
   53  SENATE,  THE  SPEAKER OF THE ASSEMBLY, THE CHAIRMAN OF THE SENATE ENERGY
   54  AND TELECOMMUNICATIONS COMMITTEE AND THE CHAIRMAN OF THE ASSEMBLY ENERGY
   55  COMMITTEE.

       S. 1056                             3

    1    2. THE STUDY SHALL INCLUDE, AT A MINIMUM, AN ASSESSMENT OF EACH OF THE
    2  FOLLOWING:  THE CURRENT AND PROJECTED ADEQUACY OF  THE  ELECTRIC  TRANS-
    3  MISSION  SYSTEM OVER THE TEN YEAR PERIOD BEGINNING ON THE EFFECTIVE DATE
    4  OF THIS SECTION, WITH SPECIFIC FOCUS ON  SYSTEM  CONGESTION  WITHIN  THE
    5  STATE.  THE  ASSESSMENT  SHALL  EXAMINE: (I) ADEQUACY OF TRANSMISSION IN
    6  DENSELY POPULATED AREAS, INCLUDING LOAD  POCKETS;  (II)  THE  EXTENT  TO
    7  WHICH TRANSMISSION CONGESTION IMPEDES THE DEVELOPMENT OF A FULLY COMPET-
    8  ITIVE  WHOLESALE ELECTRICITY MARKET; (III) INVESTMENT IN INFRASTRUCTURE,
    9  INCLUDING CAPITAL IMPROVEMENTS, EXPANSIONS, AND  MAINTENANCE;  (IV)  NEW
   10  TRANSMISSION  TECHNOLOGIES  THAT  CAN INCREASE TRANSMISSION CAPABILITIES
   11  OVER EXISTING FACILITIES, INCLUDING AN ASSESSMENT OF THE COSTS AND BENE-
   12  FITS OF SUCH TECHNOLOGIES; AND (V)  WORKFORCE  ADEQUACY,  INCLUDING  THE
   13  AVAILABILITY OF SKILLED LABORERS AND THE ADEQUACY OF SKILLS TRAINING AND
   14  APPRENTICESHIP PROGRAMS.
   15    3.  THE  AUTHORITY SHALL CONSULT WITH ENTITIES THAT HAVE RESOURCES AND
   16  EXPERTISE TO ASSIST IN SUCH INVESTIGATION,  INCLUDING  THE  LONG  ISLAND
   17  POWER  AUTHORITY,  THE  POWER  AUTHORITY  OF  THE STATE OF NEW YORK, THE
   18  DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC SERVICE, AND THE MEMBERS OF THE NEW YORK POWER POOL
   19  OR ITS SUCCESSOR OR SUCCESSORS.
   20    S 1855-B. NATURAL GAS SUPPLY AND INFRASTRUCTURE STUDY. 1. THE AUTHORI-
   21  TY SHALL UNDERTAKE A STUDY OF ISSUES, INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED  TO  THE
   22  SUPPLY,  TRANSPORTATION,  PIPELINE CAPACITY, DISTRIBUTION AND STORAGE OF
   23  NATURAL GAS IN NEW YORK STATE. THE AUTHORITY MAY CONTRACT WITH AN  INDE-
   24  PENDENT  AND  COMPETITIVELY SELECTED CONTRACTOR TO UNDERTAKE SUCH STUDY.
   25  THE AUTHORITY SHALL PREPARE A REPORT ON  ITS  FINDINGS  AND  LEGISLATIVE
   26  RECOMMENDATIONS.  ON OR BEFORE SEPTEMBER FIRST, TWO THOUSAND TWELVE, THE
   27  AUTHORITY SHALL TRANSMIT SUCH REPORT  TO  THE  GOVERNOR,  THE  TEMPORARY
   28  PRESIDENT  OF  THE  SENATE, THE SPEAKER OF THE ASSEMBLY, THE CHAIRMAN OF
   29  THE SENATE ENERGY AND TELECOMMUNICATIONS COMMITTEE AND THE  CHAIRMAN  OF
   30  THE ASSEMBLY ENERGY COMMITTEE.
   31    2. THE STUDY SHALL INCLUDE, AT A MINIMUM, AN ASSESSMENT OF EACH OF THE
   32  FOLLOWING:
   33    (A)  CURRENT  UTILITY  PRACTICES IN PROCURING THE COMMODITY OF NATURAL
   34  GAS AND A COMPARISON, BY UTILITY TERRITORY IN THE STATE, OF  IMPACTS  ON
   35  RATES  FOR  END-USE CUSTOMERS; (B) THE CURRENT AND PROJECTED ADEQUACY OF
   36  THE  NATURAL  GAS  INFRASTRUCTURE,  INCLUDING  TRANSPORTATION,  PIPELINE
   37  CAPACITY,  DISTRIBUTION  AND  STORAGE IN NEW YORK STATE; (C) ADEQUACY OF
   38  TRANSPORTATION AND DISTRIBUTION IN DENSELY POPULATED AREAS OF THE  STATE
   39  AND  IN  RURAL  AREAS  OF  THE  STATE; (D) INVESTMENT IN INFRASTRUCTURE,
   40  INCLUDING CAPITAL IMPROVEMENTS, UTILIZATION OF  NEW  TECHNOLOGY,  EXPAN-
   41  SIONS,  AND MAINTENANCE; (E) THE ADEQUACY OF TRANSPORTATION AND DISTRIB-
   42  UTION INFRASTRUCTURE IN AREAS WHERE NATURAL GAS FUELED ELECTRIC GENERAT-
   43  ING PLANTS ARE PROPOSED; (F) INDIGENOUS SOURCES OF NATURAL  GAS  IN  THE
   44  STATE;  (G)  WORKFORCE  ADEQUACY,  INCLUDING THE AVAILABILITY OF SKILLED
   45  LABORERS  AND  THE  ADEQUACY  OF  SKILLS  TRAINING  AND   APPRENTICESHIP
   46  PROGRAMS;  AND  (H)  THE  POTENTIAL IMPACT OF DISTRIBUTED GENERATION AND
   47  COMBINED HEAT AND  POWER  SYSTEMS  ON  NATURAL  GAS  TRANSPORTATION  AND
   48  DISTRIBUTION SYSTEM ADEQUACY.
   49    S  1855-C.  COMPREHENSIVE ENERGY MANAGEMENT PLAN.  1. THE AUTHORITY IS
   50  HEREBY AUTHORIZED AND DIRECTED  TO  CONDUCT  A  COMPREHENSIVE  STUDY  TO
   51  ANALYZE  THE  ELECTRICITY AND STEAM CAPACITY AND POWER DISTRIBUTION GRID
   52  CONDITIONS IN THE DOWNSTATE REGION OF THE STATE.  FOR PURPOSES  OF  THIS
   53  SECTION,  "DOWNSTATE"  SHALL  BE DEFINED AS THAT REGION LOCATED SOUTH OF
   54  THE MILLWOOD - SOUTH TRANSMISSION INTERFACE.  SUCH STUDY SHALL  INCLUDE,
   55  BUT SHALL NOT BE LIMITED TO:

       S. 1056                             4

    1    (A)  AN  ANALYSIS OF PROJECTED POWER NEEDS AND AN ASSESSMENT OF EXIST-
    2  ING:
    3    (I) GENERATING FACILITIES WITH A CAPACITY OF TWENTY MEGAWATTS OR MORE;
    4    (II) POWER GRID CAPACITY AND LOAD POCKETS;
    5    (III) NATURAL GAS AND OTHER FUEL SOURCE CAPACITY;
    6    (IV) SUBSTATION TRANSFORMERS; AND
    7    (V) EMERGENCY GENERATORS;
    8    (B) AN ANALYSIS OF FUTURE POWER NEEDS;
    9    (C) AN ENVIRONMENTAL ASSESSMENT OF GENERATING FACILITIES WITH A CAPAC-
   10  ITY OF TWENTY MEGAWATTS OR MORE, INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO:
   11    (I) EMISSIONS;
   12    (II) WATER IMPACTS;
   13    (III) LAND USE IMPACTS;
   14    (IV) TRAFFIC IMPACTS; AND
   15    (V) NOISE IMPACTS;
   16    (D) THE IDENTIFICATION OF AREAS OF OVERSATURATION OF POWER FACILITIES;
   17  AND
   18    (E) AN ASSESSMENT OF ALTERNATIVES, SUCH AS:
   19    (I) ENERGY EFFICIENCY;
   20    (II) LOAD CURTAILMENT;
   21    (III) CLEAN DISTRIBUTED GENERATION; AND
   22    (IV) CO-GENERATION.
   23    2.  THE  AUTHORITY  SHALL SUBMIT A COPY OF SUCH STUDY TO THE GOVERNOR,
   24  THE TEMPORARY PRESIDENT OF THE SENATE, THE SPEAKER OF THE ASSEMBLY,  THE
   25  CHAIRMAN  OF  THE SENATE ENERGY AND TELECOMMUNICATIONS COMMITTEE AND THE
   26  CHAIRMAN OF THE ASSEMBLY ENERGY COMMITTEE NO LATER THAN  JANUARY  FIRST,
   27  TWO THOUSAND TWELVE.
   28    3.  UPON COMPLETION OF THE STUDY CONDUCTED PURSUANT TO SUBDIVISION ONE
   29  OF THIS SECTION, THE AUTHORITY SHALL DEVELOP  AN  OVERALL  COMPREHENSIVE
   30  ENERGY  MANAGEMENT PLAN.   SUCH PLAN SHALL TAKE INTO ACCOUNT THE RESULTS
   31  AND FINDINGS OF SUCH STUDY, AND SHALL INCLUDE, BUT SHALL NOT BE  LIMITED
   32  TO THE FOLLOWING:
   33    (A) AN OUTLINE OF GUIDELINES AND REQUIREMENTS FOR SITING POWER PLANTS;
   34    (B)  THE  RESEARCH OF POTENTIAL SITES FOR FUTURE POWER PLANT LOCATIONS
   35  THAT MEET THE GUIDELINES AND REQUIREMENTS ESTABLISHED PURSUANT TO  PARA-
   36  GRAPH  (A) OF THIS SUBDIVISION AND ARE NOT LOCATED IN AREAS OF OVERSATU-
   37  RATION;
   38    (C) AN IDENTIFICATION OF EXISTING PLANTS THAT SHOULD BE  TARGETED  FOR
   39  RE-POWERING WITH MORE EFFICIENT GENERATORS; AND
   40    (D) A REQUIREMENT THAT AT LEAST TWO PUBLIC HEARINGS BE HELD WITHIN THE
   41  DOWNSTATE  REGION  DESCRIBED  IN  SUBDIVISION ONE OF THIS SECTION WITHIN
   42  SIXTY DAYS OF THE PUBLICATION  OF  SUCH  MANAGEMENT  PLAN,  AND  PROVIDE
   43  ADEQUATE OPPORTUNITY FOR WRITTEN TESTIMONY REGARDING SUCH PLAN.
   44    4.  THE  AUTHORITY  SHALL SUBMIT A COPY OF SUCH MANAGEMENT PLAN TO THE
   45  GOVERNOR, THE TEMPORARY PRESIDENT OF THE  SENATE,  THE  SPEAKER  OF  THE
   46  ASSEMBLY,  THE  CHAIRMAN  OF  THE  SENATE  ENERGY AND TELECOMMUNICATIONS
   47  COMMITTEE AND THE CHAIRMAN OF THE ASSEMBLY  ENERGY  COMMITTEE  NO  LATER
   48  THAN SEPTEMBER FIRST, TWO THOUSAND TWELVE.
   49    S 5. This act shall take effect immediately.
